awd_titl_txt: Transport of Non-Spherical Particles in Wavy Flows
awd_abstract_narration:
Plastic debris is a growing environmental concern for the world's oceans; several million metric tons of plastic enter the oceans each year. Much of the plastic debris is present as small, irregular particles five millimeters or less in length, called "microplastics," that pose a threat to marine organisms, the environment, and human health. This research project involves extending state-of-the-art research about particle-laden flows to situations relevant to the microplastics problem. Irregular particles are being studied in wavy flows to understand how to control the transport and sorting of these microparticles in the ocean and in near-shore environments. Both laboratory experiments and modeling are being performed and tools for predicting the motion of microplastics in the ocean and the length of time particles spend near the shore are being developed. The research team is working with earth scientists, biologists, and policy makers to integrate the resulting knowledge into conservation efforts. The investigators also are closely engaged in mentoring graduate students, teaching undergraduates about the transport of marine microplastics, and creating outreach activities for high school and middle school students. 

This research project is identifying and classifying the mechanisms that control transport and tumbling of anisotropic particles in wavy environments and quantifying the dispersion rate and sorting of these particles based on size and shape in waves. While particle-laden flows are well studied in certain limits, the complexities of particle-laden flows involving large, anisotropic particles in surface gravity waves is complicated by the wide range of length and time scales involved. In particular, direct numerical simulations become computationally expensive, and as a result, experiments are a crucial tool. The investigators have advanced facilities for generating and quantifying wavy flows and are performing experiments and empirical modeling to characterize particle transport in these flows. The experiments will allow the researchers to address how anisotropic particles, like microplastics with their additional degrees of freedom for rotational motion relative to spherical particles, may lead to complex dynamics when coupled with waves, turbulence, and the stratification found in the ocean. A better understanding of these interactions will provide guidance regarding assumptions going into simplified models. The governing nondimensional parameters (the density ratio, wave Froude number, and Stokes number) are being varied over ranges relevant to those in the ocean. Pointwise flow characteristics and turbulence are being measured using laser Doppler anemometry; waves are being characterized via wave gauges; and the mean transport due to Stokes drift is being measured via particle tracking. Anisotropic particles, including rods, disks, and ellipsoids, are being created via 3D printing, and the dispersion of these particles is being measured by releasing a cloud of particles and then measuring the phase-averaged shape of the cloud over time and space. The results are expected to enhance our understanding of the fundamental physics governing the transport of non-spherical particles in waves and to inform the empirical modeling of microplastics in the ocean.

por.por_cntn:
The research objectives of this proposal were to describe how microplastics (irregularly shaped plastic objects less than 5mm in size) are transported locally in the ocean and how they sort based on size and shape. Specifically, we focused on how non-spherical, neutrally-buoyant, and negatively-buoyant particles are transported in flows typically present near the ocean surface and in the near-shore environment. Thus, the specific aims of our project were to (1) identify and classify the mechanisms that control transport and tumbling of anisotropic particles in wavy environments and (2) quantify the dispersion rate and sorting of these particles in the presence of waves and currents.

To achieve these aims, we used a combination of laboratory experiments and empirical modeling to characterize particle transport in idealized wavy flows that are representative of those found in the ocean. This work was structured so as to be relevant to the particular problem of microplastic transport as well as to non-spherical particle-laden flows in general. While the primary focus of this work was gaining an understanding of the fundamental fluid mechanics associated with the transport of non-spherical particles, we also worked to translate our research into a solutions-oriented framework to help inform conservation efforts in the ocean.

Our project was broken up into three main phases. In the first phase, we conducted a set of empirical modeling studies, and developed a numerical model to start examining non-spherical orientation dynamics in waves. We also quantified, using empirical means, the settling velocity difference between non-spherical particles in waves and in still water to address the preferential orientation of non-spherical particles under waves. We discovered, using numerical simulations, that non-spherical particles tend to adopt a preferential orientation under waves in the limit of low inertia. We used theoretical analysis to support this preferential orientation finding and linked it to the same dynamics that determine the Stokes? drift effect in waves.

In the second phase, we performed a set of experiments in a wavy flow with simultaneous fluid tracer particle tracking and large non-spherical particle tracking. This was done to get a sense of the overall sinking behavior of the non-spherical particles. Along these lines we also developed data analysis tools for the experimental data to determine the effects of waves on particle settling velocity. We found that the settling velocity is an important parameter in modeling particle transport. Laminar waves can both enhance and decrease particle settling velocity depending on the Reynolds number of the particles. Furthermore, we found that the free surface of the waves can have a profound effect on the dispersal of particles in the vertical direction, and that a shear flow superimposed on the waves can both alter the preferred orientation of a particle and cause the particle to move away from the preferred orientation.

In the third phase, we designed, built, and performed a new experiment focused on how shape affects the dispersion of particles in a mean current with and without waves. In this experiment, we released negatively-buoyant, non-spherical particles at the surface of a nominally laminar channel flow with and without waves. From the landing positions of the particles, we analyzed how the mean distance traveled by the particles and particle dispersion varied with shape and the presence of waves. While we are currently still analyzing the results from these experiments it is clear that the irregularly shaped particles disperse more in flows with current and waves than in flows with currents alone, and that particle shape has a strong effect on dispersion as well. As part of the third phase, we also designed and built a novel wavemaker using a Scotch-yoke principle to create the waves in the channel. This is shown in Figure 1.

Finally, we considered the effects of waves on the sampling of microplastics with a towed net, and we showed that waves have the ability to lower the measured concentrations relative to nets sampling without the influence of waves. We find that waves result in non-uniform horizontal distributions of particles with more particles under the wave crests than the troughs. All of these results are presented and summarized in a set of 5 archival journal articles.
